s.text: All the economic research suggests that there is no difference in the efficiency of small and large firms once a firm grows beyond a minimum size.
It is for this reason that Census Bureau data for the last 50 years show no evidence of any change in the employment size distribution of firms and establishments.
It is for this reason that Census Bureau data for the last 50 years show no evidence of any change in the employment size distribution of firms and establishments.
We need a more dynamic model to get a real sense of what's going on.
Times on July 6, which referred to "98 percent of all jobs since 1989 being created by businesses with fewer than four employees."
However, Census Bureau counts show that during the phase of rapid growth between 1982 to 1987, an equal number of firms in each size class reported job gains as losses.
However, Census Bureau counts show that during the phase of rapid growth between 1982 to 1987, an equal number of firms in each size class reported job gains as losses.
For example, in his paper titled "On the Size Distribution of Employment and Establishments," Jonathan Leonard finds that large firms are the main job generators.

Getting a good fix on this phenomenon isn't easy, because most government data are collected to measure monthly employment changes, and there are no current data available on gross job flows by business size.
Predictably, SBA's counts show a totally different (and false) picture (see bottom of Figure 3).
